data.text: Which Handlebar Satellite Navigation Device for Bike Touring?

hello everyone... I'm a seasoned cyclist, during my whole life... Mtb single-track mostly however not as tech savvy as some... I want to ask what handlebar "satnav" device do people use, recommend... I usually refer to my phone ! I like "cycle travel" UK website routes etc but have stumbled into komoot as well... do I use my phone or a garmin ?? my picture is me doing the mid wales Radnor ring trip this spring...on my new thorn nomad bike.... I plan to do big world trips as I ease up on work .....

From my experience so far, I would highly recommend you to invest into a good navigation app like Komoot, rather than a Garmin. If your purpose is travelling, this is far better because Garmin maps are sometimes... limited. I am now travelling in Turkey, I now use exclusively Komoot, my Garmin remains as a nice decoration and to upload my rides on Strava😅

data.text: Hi to all people above. I have the 830 and used it to ride across the country. Overall, I was dissatisfied due to its inconsistency. I seemed to take a long time to find the signal. When I would intentionally go off course to make a stop, maybe just a 100 yards or so, and then resume, it would keep telling me that I am off course while knowing full well that I was on course. Eventually, it would catch up. This was very frustrating. When it did tell me I was off course I always stopped and checked a map or Google Maps to verify that I was off course. When in battery saver mode it seemed to last all day. It does charge quickly. Does the 1030 seem temperamental? I rode with someone with a Wahoo Bolt and it was solid. Comments welcome.

data.text: I plan in Kamoot, and it's connected with my Hammerhead Karoo GPS unit. If the Karoo is connected to the Internet (I make my phone WiFi hotspot) it pulls the information about the planned route from Kamoot. Karoo also has an option of downloading the maps of an area, which I do for the area I cycle in. Then I use the Karoo in offline mode, and it gives me Kamoot route and options of rerouting. I love the unit as it has a very good heigh map and climbing screen which shows me the gradient (current and every 200-300m in the next kilometar), and how long is the climb (eg it says 2km/150m, so I know I'll have to climb 150m in the next 2 km - 7.5% average gradient)

data.text: I have v1 so cannot say how current V2 is holding. There is a FB group which can answer that. My 3 years old V1 uses 7-8% of battery per hour (I tend to turn on auto pause so on tours the whole day is one ride and I don't worry about stopping it) when no additional sensors is used, up to 11-12% with heart rate and cadence sensors. Screen is at minimum or in the first 25%, even on that settings it can be read on direct sunlight without a problem. And as I take stops at least every 2 hours (I usually something interesting enough to take a photo), I plug in the powerbank for 10-15 minutes. Had it up to 15 hours (with sensors) in a day that way without a problem.

data.text: Having a dedicated head unit like a Garmin is a good idea. I have nearly cooked an iPhone using it for nav. Mobile phone processors are not really designed for nav, they over work and overheat. If you are going to use a phone it is best to only look at it when you think you need to change direction, then shut the screen down. You can get some apps that allow off line navigation, but again screen time gobbles up battery. I use a Garmin Edge 520 Plus. This is a very compact unit and is one of Garmin's cheaper options. Be aware the 520 Plus have mapping the 520 standard does not. Battery life running navigation is about 8 hours. Just using the device as a bike computer gives about 15 hours. For route planning I use the free versions of either Ridewithgps or Komoot, and then export the route to my Garmin. The easiest is to route plan on a PC/laptop and then transfer. Both RWGPS and Komoot have phone apps to, but I have not used them for route planning yet. There are tutorials on youtube on how to easily transfer routes to your Garmin.

data.text: I've been going through the same process as you. I started with an android phone but fried it in Madrid's hot sun. I did a post on thus site a couple of weeks back. I'm about to buy a wahoo elemnt roam. What I learnt. Wahoo has free world wide maps maps. Garmin provide maps in the region to you are in. Kamoot has a free version, but you have to pay to get access to the premium cycle package and to have kamoot offline and also to export files. I been using OSMAND for route planning and will continue to do so. OSMAND lets you plan car routes avoiding motorways and other major roads. This has been great at times as bike mode and kamoot create some funky routes. The wahoo has buttons not touch screen from what I've read it's therefore better in the rain. Wahoos display is meant to be easier to read in bright sun. In my posts others recommended cycle.travel for route planning. It looks awesome for UK and Europe where I'm currently to touring!!! You can download routes to be transferred to GPS or other apps. Hope that helps.

data.text: Garmin Edge 1030 with UK Ordnance Survey mapping, outside of UK or even Europe I download the relevant open source cycle maps (free). Sometimes for final mile I’ll use phone to get to a campsite or Airbnb. I route with a variety of services but find an already completed route is always better than a computer generated. RideWithGPS is great, I convert to Garmin on Connect website and sync to device. By only using the line of your route on the map to guide you (called a crumb trail) versus “turn by turn routing” (think car sat nav style) the battery lasts for multiple days of routing and recording. When you’ve done a good route share it back to the community via Garmin or STRAVA or Komoot or with RideWithGPS. Google maps (on cycle routing option) is a good final mile or last resort.

data.text: I have used the GAIA GPS app to ride and hike on five continents and I highly recommend it. All smart phones have a GPS chip on them and you don’t need a mobile phone (cellular) connection to use your phone as a GPS when using an app such as GAIA, Komoot etc. You can down load maps and plan your routes when on-line and then go onto Airplane mode when navigating and recording your route. This way your battery should last all day (depending on its type/age). Of course take a spare phone and paper map as back up.
